caption: #: -- ; A 39-year-old Malaysian man was arrested for attempting to smuggle drugs, including about 3,272g of cannabis and 1,709g of Ice, through Woodlands Checkpoint. Based on information received from Integrated Targeting Centre, the Malaysian man was referred for enhanced checks at Woodlands Checkpoint on 22 December 2025. ICA officers uncovered two black bundles believed to contain controlled drugs in the mans bag. CNB officers were immediately alerted to the detection and conducted further checks. A total of 7 bundles believed to contain controlled drugs were found. The bundles contained about 3,272g of cannabis and 1,709g of Ice. The drugs seized have an estimated worth of more than $237,000 and could potentially feed the addiction of about 1,440 abusers for a week.Investigations are ongoing. Under Section 7 of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, those who import into or export from Singapore more than 250g of methamphetamine, or 500g of cannabis, may face the death penalty. CNB will continue to work with ICA to prevent attempts to smuggle drugs across our borders.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

Its gifting season! The best celebrations are built on real laughter, genuine connections and memories worth keeping Amidst the festivities, heres a reminder to protect ourselves and our loved ones from the dangers of drug abuse. CNB wishes all a Merry Christmas! DrugFreeSG
How does CNB help ex-abusers stay drugfree and avoid relapse? Swipe to find out more about the drug supervision regime, and how it better supports reintegration. Read more at CNBExplains DrugFreeSG

#: , , - - Three separate enforcement operations were jointly conducted by officers from CNB, the Singapore Police Force (SPF), Immigration & Checkpoints Authority (ICA), Health Sciences Authority (HSA), Singapore Customs and Ministry of Manpower (MOM) at migrant worker dormitories from 8 to 11 December, as part of sustained efforts to clamp down on illegal activities including drug offences and other crimes. Seven Bangladeshi men aged between 20 and 40 were arrested for suspected drug-related offences.A 25-year-old man was arrested at a dormitory near Jurong West for suspected drug consumption offences, while two men aged 23 and 29 were arrested at a dormitory near Seletar for suspected drug consumption and trafficking offences respectively. A small amount of Ice and various drug paraphernalia were seized from the 29-year-old man and his living area.Another operation was launched at a dormitory near Choa Chu Kang, and four men aged 20 to 40 were arrested for suspected drug-related offences. A small amount of Ice and various drug paraphernalia were seized from a 24-year-old suspect.Superintendent Lim Wee Beng, Deputy Director of Enforcement Division said: CNB will take decisive action against drug activities, no matter where it occurs in our communities, workplaces, or residential premises. Drugs have no place in Singapore, and those involved in drug activities will face the full force of the law. We remain committed to protect the safety and well-being of all, including our migrant workers, and will continue to work with our law enforcement partners to detect, disrupt, and prevent drug-related threats. We thank our partners at SPF, ICA, HSA, Singapore Customs and MOM for their invaluable support in these operations.Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

Get ready for an adrenaline-pumping operation with CNBs Special Task Force (STF) officers to take down syndicates and keep Singapore drug-free. Trained for the toughest missions, STF officers combine their peak physical fitness, sharp tactical instincts, and specialised skills with teamwork, strategy and discipline to execute their operations successfully. Watch the Home Teams Honour and Unity micro-drama series on Mediacorps TikTok and YouTube Shorts.OneHomeTeam HonourAndUnity BehindTheScenes

I was scared to say no to drugs, I was afraid I'd lose my so-called friends. I thought drugs made my problems disappear, but I became so addicted I couldn't eat or sleep properly and was always chasing after that same high. Instead of helping me fit in, drugs made me lose those who matters. Ive made many, many mistakes, so I understand if others are careful around someone like me. But I hope they'll look beyond the surface, understand the circumstances and find the courage to let us prove we've changed. Its not impossible, because real relationships and connections allowed me to have that second chance. - S, Former Drug Abuser.DrugFreeSG SingaporeansAgainstDrugs SGAD

#: - CNB led an enforcement operation against drug abuse and trafficking and other criminal and illicit activities at a foreign worker dormitory located in Woodlands from 27 Nov to 28 Nov 2025. The operation involved officers from the Singapore Police Force (SPF), Ministry of Manpower (MOM), Immigration and Checkpoints Authority (ICA) and Health Sciences Authority (HSA) as part of sustained efforts to clamp down on illegal activities.A total of 12 male foreign nationals 11 Bangladeshis and a Myanmar national were arrested for suspected drug-related offences. The men are aged between 23 and 40 years old. Among them, a 34-year-old Bangladeshi man was arrested for suspected drug trafficking and drug consumption offences. [Continued in captions] Investigations into the drug activities of all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

#: - - - ; , - - CNB arrested 140 suspected drug offenders in an island-wide anti-drug operation from 10 to 21 November 2025. A total of about 4,354g of heroin, 1,225g of cannabis, 1,092g of Ice, 135g of Ecstasy tablets, one Erimin-5 tablet, one bottle of methadone, small amount of ketamine and numerous vape-related products including 316 e-vaporisers and 1,342 e-vaporiser pods believed to contain etomidate were seized. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth more than $892,000. The heroin, Ice and cannabis seized could potentially feed the addiction of 2,873 abusers for a week. Some of the areas covered during this island-wide operation included Bedok, Bugis, Bukit Batok, Geylang, Jurong, Sembawang and Yishun.On 13 November, CNB officers launched an operation at a residential unit near Yishun Ring Road which saw the arrest of a 36-year-old Singaporean man for suspected drug-related offences. Cash amounting to SGD5,322.90, MYR442.05, BND155 and THB5 were later seized from the man. CNB officers then searched the mans car, where vape-related products including 304 e-vaporisers and 1,337 e-vaporiser pods believed to contain etomidate were seized. Also on 13 November, CNB officers raided a residential unit near Jurong East Avenue, arresting four Singaporeans a 53-year-old woman for suspected drug trafficking offences and three men, aged 61, 65 and 67 for suspected drug abuse. About 1,031g of heroin, 131g of Ice, 121g of Ecstasy tablets, one Erimin-5 tablet, drug paraphernalia and cash amounting to SGD6,067 were seized from the unit.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

Heroin chic was defended as a more authentic take on beauty, a rejection of polished perfection in favour of something raw and unfiltered.But what was framed as real was ironically a naive glamourisation of pain, detached from the true consequences of drug abuse.Whats troubling is that this is not mere historythe same playbook persists today in existing fashion and diet trends, elevating unhealthy behaviours as normal.Fads rise and fade, but they leave a mark on us for far longer. Our challenge? To pause and reconsider what it is that were really being sold.In collaboration with .drugfreesg

#: ; - On 30 October, CNB officers conducted two etomidate operations. Numerous vape-related products including 115 e-vaporiser pods and 13 e-vaporisers believed to contain etomidate, and cash of about SGD4,924.20 were seized.One location was near Yishun Ring Road, where a 42-year-old Singaporean man was arrested at his residential unit for suspected drug offences, with numerous vape-related products and SGD3,900 in cash seized. Officers conducted a follow-up search of the rubbish chute linked to the unit and recovered a total of about 109 e-vaporiser pods and 11 e-vaporisers believed to contain etomidate.The other operation was launched at a residential unit near Fernvale Lane, where a 31-year-old Singaporean woman was arrested for suspected drug offences. Officers seized numerous vaping products including six e-vaporiser pods and two e-vaporisers believed to contain etomidate and SGD1,024.20 in cash from within the unit and the womans belongings.Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug.Under the MDA, those who import, sell or distribute etomidate-laced e-vaporisers will face prosecution.Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

#: CNB and work closely at the checkpoints and take action against those who flout Singapore's drug laws. On 17 Oct, CNB officers were alerted by ICA officers at the Singapore Cruise Centre to a 50-year-old Singaporean male who tested positive for methamphetamine. A search of his belongings uncovered controlled drugs including 5 Erimin-5 tablets, 3 Ecstasy tablets, 3.78g of Ice, 1 vape device with attached vape pod, 1 vape pod and various drug-related paraphernalia. CNB officers subsequently escorted him to his residential unit, where 15.5g of Ice and drug-related paraphernalia were recovered. Investigations are ongoing. The consumption, possession, trafficking, import or export of any controlled drugs is an offence under Singapores Misuse of Drugs Act (MDA). The public is reminded to stay away from drugs even when overseas. Under the MDA, Singaporeans and Permanent Residents will be liable for the same drug consumption offence regardless of where the controlled drugs were consumed.

The public is reminded to stay away from drugs even when overseas. We all know that drugs pose negative consequences, so why do we sometimes find memes relating to drug abuse funny?Through the softening language we use to joke around with our friends, we seem to have subconsciously redefined and normalised the act of drug abuse. We may consider ourselves above external pressures, but when were surrounded by a deep-rooted influence of everyday casual language, its important to pause and examine our shifting boundaries.In collaboration with .drugfreesg

#: CNB arrested four male foreign nationals, aged between 24 and 36, for suspected drug offences in an operation conducted on 22 October.In the late morning of 22 October, acting on information received, CNB officers launched an operation at a foreign worker residential lodging near Woodlands Ave 1, which led to the arrest of four male foreign nationals one for suspected drug trafficking offences and three others for suspected drug abuse. A search was conducted on the men and their living area, and a total of 68g of cannabis, 18g of Ice, 29 Yaba tablets and various drug paraphernalia were seized.Superintendent Royce Chua, Commanding Officer of Enforcement F and L Division, said: "CNB regularly engages the community, which includes our migrant worker community, to raise awareness on the harms of drugs and Singapores zero tolerance stance against drugs. CNB will not hesitate to take tough enforcement action against drug traffickers and offenders, and will spare no effort to detect, disrupt, and dismantle drug operations to keep Singapore safe.Under Section 5 of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, it is an offence for a person, on his or her own behalf, or on behalf of any other person, whether or not that other person is in Singapore, to traffic in a controlled drug, offer to traffic in a controlled drug; or to do or offer to do any act preparatory to or for the purpose of trafficking in a controlled drug.Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio
CNB wishes all a happy Deepavali

#: - - ; CNB arrested 74 suspected drug offenders in an island-wide anti-drug operation from 13 to 17 October 2025. A total of about 2,504g of cannabis, 158g of ketamine, 76g of heroin, 73g of Ice, 12g of Ecstasy, 40 Erimin-5 tablets and numerous vape related products including 42 e-vaporiser pods believed to contain etomidate were seized. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth more than $68,000. The heroin, Ice and cannabis seized could potentially feed the addiction of 436 abusers for a week. Areas covered during this island-wide operation included Ang Mo Kio, Balestier, Clementi, Punggol, Woodlands and Yishun. On 13 October, CNB officers intercepted a motorcycle at a junction along Yishun Avenue 1 and arrested a 36-year-old Singaporean male rider, for suspected drug trafficking offences. A search of the man and the motorcycle found a total of about 2,369g of cannabis, 156g of ketamine, 11g of Ice, 11g of Ecstasy, 40 Erimin-5 tablets, and drug paraphernalia. On the same evening, CNB officers launched a follow-up operation near Compassvale Walk and arrested a 27-year-old Singaporean man for suspected drug trafficking offences. Drug paraphernalia were seized from the males residence in Punggol. Separately, on 15 October, CNB officers launched an operation near Clementi Avenue 1 and arrested a 26-year-old Singaporean woman for suspected drug trafficking offences. The woman was with her 19-month-old daughter during the arrest. A search of the woman found a total of 7 e-vaporiser pods and 2 e-vaporisers believed to contain etomidate. Appropriate arrangements were made to ensure that the welfare of the child was taken care of. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

Lifes a long race real strength is knowing when to pull over for support.Dont wait till your engine gives out. Take your pit stop to refuel, recover, and get back on track. DrugFreeSG YouAreNotAlone

On 4 Oct, 28 Home Team Volunteer Network volunteers attended the Learning Journey held at CNB. Volunteers learnt video and photo editing skills, engaged in a meaningful dialogue about CNBs annual campaign, Drug Victims Remembrance Day, and gained insights into CNB's work through demonstrations of saliva test kits, urine testing procedures and hair analysis. To wrap up the session, volunteers had the opportunity to join a fireside chat with Deputy Director (Policy & Administration), CNB, Mr Sng Chern Hong, where they exchanged ideas and perspectives on drug advocacy.Thank you to everyone who joined us!Keen to make a difference? Sign up as a DrugFreeSG Advocate at HomeTeamVolunteers

As part of our Whole of Government efforts against vaping, CNB partners closely with HSA to support investigations and enforcement against trafficking syndicates. From 2 to 4 Sep, CNB conducted a three-day specialised training to further enhance HSA enforcement officers tactical skills, covering statement recording, search procedures, urine collection, arrest techniques, and self-defence. Swipe through for highlights

Its Time to Vote! DrugFreeSG Video Competition Popularity Contest is LIVE! Your vote matters! All video entries are now up, and its time to support your favourite film in the Popularity Contest! How to Vote:1 Watch all the amazing video entries.2 Vote for the one that inspires, moves, or challenges you the most!3 Share and encourage your friends to vote too! Voting Period: 6-12 October 2025 Cast your vote here: Exciting Prizes for Voters & Winners! 2 lucky voters will win S$50 Shopping Vouchersso dont miss out! Most Popular Videos (1 Youth & 1 Young Adults) will each win S$100 Shopping Vouchers/Grab Vouchers! Winners of the Popularity Contest will be informed via email from 17 October 2025 with prize collection details.Your vote helps amplify meaningful stories and support young filmmakers who are making a difference! Which video gets your vote? Cast it now! DrugFreeSG PopularityContest VoteNow Uninfluenced AreWeUninfluenced

#: - - ; - CNB arrested 77 suspected drug offenders in an island-wide anti-drug operation from 21 to 26 September 2025. A total of about 351g of heroin, 99g of Ice, 69g of cannabis, 10g of ketamine, one Ecstasy tablet, one bottle of methadone, numerous vape-related products including 527 e-vaporiser pods believed to contain etomidate and cash amounting to $4,228.70 were seized. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth more than $74,000. The heroin, Ice and cannabis seized can potentially feed the addiction of 235 abusers for a week.Drug trafficking suspects were arrested from various locations across a few days. On 21 and 24 September, CNB officers raided residential units near New Bridge Road and Champions Way and arrested a 60-year-old Singaporean male and a 46-year-old Singaporean woman from the respective locations for drug trafficking offences. About 106g of heroin and 26g of Ice were recovered from the unit at New Bridge Road, while 143g of heroin, 18g of Ice, 65g of cannabis and 10g of ketamine were seized from the latter.On 25 September, CNB officers raided residential units near Hougang Street 51 and Buangkok Crescent, where two Singaporean male drug trafficking suspects aged 28 and 29 were arrested from the respective locations. Numerous vape-related products including 524 e-vaporiser pods believed to contain etomidate, and cash including $3,500 were seized from within the Hougang unit. The 29-year-old was seen discarding items out of his units bedroom window prior to arrest. Upon retrieval, the items were found to be vape-related products, including one e-vaporiser pods believed to contain etomidate. Under the MDA, those who import, sell or distribute etomidate-laced e-vaporisers will face prosecution.Investigations into all arrested suspects are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

#: . . On the morning of 20 September 2025, a 37-year-old Malaysian man was arrested for attempting to smuggle drugs in a Malaysian-registered car at Tuas Checkpoint. officers had directed the car for enhanced checks and found two black bundles suspected to contain controlled drugs, concealed within the rear boot panel. CNB officers were immediately alerted to conduct further checks, which uncovered an additional six black bundles hidden in various compartments of the car.A total of about 1,908g of heroin, 1,655g of cannabis and 268g of Ice were seized from the car. The drugs seized have an estimated worth of more than $394,000 and could potentially feed the addiction of about 1,300 abusers for a week.Investigations are ongoing. Under Section 7 of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1973, those who import into or export from Singapore more than 15g of diamorphine or pure heroin, or more than 250g of methamphetamine, or more than 500g of cannabis may face the death penalty. CNB will continue to work with ICA to prevent attempts to smuggle drugs across our borders. Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

I wanted to try everything for myself at least once before making a judgment call on it. Sometimes, these adventures led me to discover great perspectives I never would have had on my own. And other times, they went horribly wrong.Looking back, I had mistakenly assumed that embracing any and all experiences made me progressive and enlightened. After all, if people were talking about the good that they experienced with drugs, was there perhaps some truth to it that was worth exploring?I realise now that my position to even consider exploring the good in something as damaging as drugs was a result of how the harsh realities of drug abuse managed to evade me through my privilege.Dont get me wrongI still think its so important to stay receptive to different perspectives without bias, but open-mindedness is nothing without its most crucial component: critical discernment.In collaboration with .drugfreesg

From my experience, there are ex-abusers who are unable to resist the temptation and fall back into drugs.But seeing my team's commitment to a drug-free life fills me with pride and optimism. I'm happy to help them and give back to the community. I want to make a difference so they don't have to experience the same struggles I did. Peter Teo DrugFreeSG SingaporeansAgainstDrugs SGAD

#: ; The United States Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA), Central Narcotics Bureau of Singapore (CNB), Narcotics Control Bureau of Brunei Darussalam (NCB), New Zealand Customs Service, New Zealand Police, the Australian Federal Police (AFP) and Australian Border Force (ABF) have successfully disrupted a transnational drug trafficking syndicate. Close cooperation and timely exchange of intelligence between the agencies enabled the operation.In April 2025, CNB received information concerning freight parcels suspected to be carrying controlled drugs which were transiting through Singapore, and were believed to have originated from the United States and bound for New Zealand. The parcels were intercepted by CNB and found to contain more than 10kg of Ice, or methamphetamine. Through follow-up investigations, CNB identified other similar parcels bound for New Zealand and Australia. Acting on this intelligence provided by CNB, New Zealand Customs intercepted two drug-laden parcels in April 2025 and June 2025, leading to a total seizure of 10kg of methamphetamine, with an estimated street value of NZ$3 million. Additional intelligence sharing with the AFP and ABF led to the Australian authorities intercepting and seizing multiple consignments in May 2025 which in total contained about 40kg of methamphetamine and had an estimated street value of AUD$37 million, destined for Australia. The illicit substances were concealed inside furniture, mixed coffee and mustard shipments. The international drug syndicate is currently under investigation in the United States. Based on the investigation so far, DEA investigators believe that the methamphetamine originated from Mexico and was imported into the United States for delivery into more lucrative markets in the Asia-Pacific region.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

#: ; The United States Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA), Central Narcotics Bureau of Singapore (CNB), Narcotics Control Bureau of Brunei Darussalam (NCB), New Zealand Customs Service, New Zealand Police, the Australian Federal Police (AFP) and Australian Border Force (ABF) have successfully disrupted a transnational drug trafficking syndicate. Close cooperation and timely exchange of intelligence between the agencies enabled the operation.In April 2025, CNB received information concerning freight parcels suspected to be carrying controlled drugs which were transiting through Singapore, and were believed to have originated from the United States and bound for New Zealand. The parcels were intercepted by CNB and found to contain more than 10kg of Ice, or methamphetamine. Through follow-up investigations, CNB identified other similar parcels bound for New Zealand and Australia. Acting on this intelligence provided by CNB, New Zealand Customs intercepted two drug-laden parcels in April 2025 and June 2025, leading to a total seizure of 10kg of methamphetamine, with an estimated street value of NZ$3 million. Additional intelligence sharing with the AFP and ABF led to the Australian authorities intercepting and seizing multiple consignments in May 2025 which in total contained about 40kg of methamphetamine and had an estimated street value of AUD$37 million, destined for Australia. The illicit substances were concealed inside furniture, mixed coffee and mustard shipments. The international drug syndicate is currently under investigation in the United States. Based on the investigation so far, DEA investigators believe that the methamphetamine originated from Mexico and was imported into the United States for delivery into more lucrative markets in the Asia-Pacific region.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

#: - ; - . CNB launched an anti-drug operation on 10 September that saw the arrests of eight Singaporeans for suspected drug offences. Numerous vape-related products including more than 400 e-vaporiser pods believed to contain etomidate, and cash including SGD20,818, RMB498 and MYR5,800 were seized.CNB officers arrested two men (aged 26 and 28) at a void deck of a residential block near Telok Blangah Rise for suspected drug offences, with both suspects physically resisting arrest and had to be subdued by officers. 68 and five e-vaporiser pods believed to contain etomidate were recovered from the 26-year-old and 28-year-old respectively, with preliminary investigations indicating the men were conducting a drug transaction prior to the arrest. The suspects were then escorted to a unit in the same block where two additional men (aged 26 and 23) were arrested, and a search yielded 327 more e-vaporiser pods believed to contain etomidate.Four other Singaporeans were arrested in separate CNB operations the same evening for suspected drug offences. Two men (aged 29 and 32) were arrested near Hougang Avenue 9, with officers seizing vape products and significant cash totalling SGD20,818, RMB498, and MYR5,800 from their unit. At Boon Lay Drive, a 23-year-old man was arrested at his residence where five e-vaporiser pods believed to contain etomidate were found, followed by the arrest of an 18-year-old woman outside the unit who was carrying one etomidate pod and had reportedly planned to collect drugs from the man.Under the MDA, those who import, sell or distribute etomidate-laced e-vaporisers will face prosecution. Investigations into the drug activities of the arrested suspects are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

From 26 to 28 August, CNB hosted 100 delegates from the ASEAN Member States, Timor-Leste, and Dialogue Partners for the 46th ASEAN Senior Officials Meeting on Drug Matters (ASOD) and Its Related Meetings.Held annually, ASOD discusses key challenges, best practices and strategies related to the regional drug problem. 2025 marks a milestone year for ASEANs drug control efforts as Member States come together to take stock of the 2016-2025 ASEAN Work Plan on Securing Communities Against Illicit Drugs.Singapore is honoured to take on Chairmanship of ASOD in 2025 during the 46th ASOD and remains committed to championing a united, zero-tolerance stance against drugs in pursuit of our shared vision of a Drug-Free ASEAN.Read the speech by Guest of Honour, Coordinating Minister for National Security and Minister for Home Affairs, Mr K Shamugam at go.gov.sg/cnb-asodspeech202546thASODdrugfreesg

Tetrahydrocannabinolcommonly known as THC for short, this is the psychoactive substance found in cannabis. It has also been the target of continued research, given the adverse health impacts reported by users and medical professionals alike.The lesson here? A drug isnt safe, just because its legal somewhere else.CNBExplains DrugFreeSG kNOwCannabis

10 Days Left! Final Call for Video Submissions! Its time to submit your entry for the DrugFreeSG Video Competition! This is your chance to showcase your creativity and make an impact. Submission Deadline: 14 September 2025 Submit Your Video Here: Important Submission Rules & Details: Video Format: Submit in horizontal format for better viewing on mobile. Teaser Reel: Submit a 30 to 60-sec teaser in vertical format for social media. (psst.. post it on socials and tag .drugfreesg) Video Length: Ensure your video is under 5 mins (excluding credits).Check out our submission guide here: [Insert Link] The Top 5 videos in each category will be announced on 13 Sept!This is the FINAL countdownShare your perspective, tell a story thats relevant to your generation, and be part of something bigger. Are you in?

The Dadah Itu Haram (DIH) campaign is a ground-up, community-driven initiative that supports anti-drug efforts. Its tagline Ambil Peduli Hadir Di Sisi means Show Care Be There, a reminder to look out for one another, be there to support each other, so that we can keep those around us safe from the harms of drugs.Want to be part of DIH campaign? More at s page

#: ; On 14 August 2025, three Singaporean men were arrested by officers from CNB in separate anti-drug operations for suspected drug offences. A total of about 1,050g of Ice, 100 Erimin-5 tablets, 9g of Ecstasy, and various drug paraphernalia were seized. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth more than $128,000 and could potentially feed the addiction of 600 abusers for a week.In the morning on 14 August, a 42-year-old Singaporean man was arrested in his residential unit near Tampines Street 86 for suspected drug offences. During the raid, CNB officers found multiple drug paraphernalia under the coffee table in the living room. The mans 10-year-old daughter was also present. In the afternoon of the same day, a 41-year-old Singaporean man was arrested in a residential unit near Jalan Kayu for suspected drug trafficking offences. During the search of the unit, officers recovered about 158g of Ice and 9g of Ecstasy. At around the same time, CNB officers raided another residential unit near Bukit Batok West Avenue 9, where a 36-year-old man was arrested for suspected drug trafficking offences. About 892g of Ice and 100 Erimin-5 tablets were seized from within the unit. The mans wife and their four children aged between one and eight years old were present in the unit. DAC Chang Gim Fook, Deputy Director (Operations) of Intelligence Division, said: CNB will continue our operational tempo to take down drug offenders. We take seriously any situation where individuals, especially children, are exposed to drugs and are subjected to unsafe environments. CNB will not hesitate to act swiftly to neutralise illegal drug activities and keep our community safe.Investigations into the drug activities of the arrested suspects are ongoing.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

CNBOnTheMove: , , - - In an island-wide anti-drug operation from 4 to 8 Aug, 79 suspected drug offenders, including 4 Malaysians, were arrested. A total of about 3457g of heroin, 909g of Ice, 3g of cannabis, among other drugs were seized. The drugs seized are estimated to be worth more than $470,000.In the evening of 5 August, a 25-year-old Malaysian man was arrested at Woodlands Checkpoint for attempting to smuggle drugs into Singapore via a Malaysian-registered car. .singapore officers found several biscuit packages suspected to contain controlled drugs and CNB officers were immediately alerted to the detection for further checks. The biscuit packages were later found to contain about 2kg of heroin and 731g of Ice.In the early morning of 6 August, acting on information received, CNB officers launched an operation near Jurong West and Henderson Road where a 53-year-old Singaporean man, a 39-year-old Malaysian man and a 43-year-old Malaysian woman were arrested for suspected drug offences. The 39-year-old Malaysian man was found with 60g of Ice and keycards to a hotel located in Geylang. CNB officers swiftly raided the hotel rooms and found a total of about 1.4kg of heroin, 62g of Ice and drug paraphernalia. Follow-up investigations led the the arrest of a 28-year-old Malaysian man for suspected drug offences.In a separate case on the morning of 5 August, ICA officers at Woodlands Checkpoint directed a motorcycle driven by a 19-year-old Singaporean man for enhanced checks. About 0.8g of Ice was subsequently uncovered under the motorcycle seat. CNB was alerted to the detection for further checks on the man and the motorcycle.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio OneHomeTeam

#: On 31 July 2025, a 33-year-old Malaysian man was arrested for attempting to smuggle drugs including about 414g of Ice in a Malaysian-registered car. officers had directed the car for enhanced checks and found a black flask containing bundles of suspected controlled drugs. CNB was alerted and conducted further checks which uncovered an additional bundle of controlled drugs hidden in the mans groin area.A total of about 414g of Ice and 46g of Ecstasy tablets was seized from the black flask and the 33-year-old man. Cash amounting to $2,947.30, THB74,920, MYR1,185.65, IDR100 and NTD10 were also seized. The drugs seized have an estimated worth of more than $52,000. The amount of Ice seized could potentially feed the addiction of about 230 abusers for a week.On the same day, through follow-up investigations, CNB launched an operation near Bras Basah and arrested a 52-year-old Singaporean man for suspected drug offences.Separately, on 2 August 2025, a 36-year-old Malaysian man was arrested for attempting to smuggle drugs including about 4,149g of cannabis in a Malaysian-registered motorcycle.ICA officers had directed the motorcycle for enhanced checks and found one packet of suspected controlled drugs. CNB was alerted and conducted further checks, and uncovered a total of four bundles from the rear box of the motorcycle. A total of about 4,149g of cannabis and 10g of ketamine was seized from the motorcycle. The drugs seized have an estimated worth of more than $100,000. The amount of cannabis seized could potentially feed the addiction of about 590 users for a week.Full story .drugfreesg linkinbio

CNBOnTheMove: Not your classic snacks In the wee hours of 10 July, CNB officers were alerted by to drug utensils found inside a Singapore-registered vehicle at Woodlands Checkpoint. Upon further checks of the vehicle, CNB officers found more drug utensils and controlled drugs, including drugs hidden in a potato chips container and a chocolate wafer bar box. The driver, a 39-year-old Singaporean man, was tested positive for the presence of drugs. As part of the follow-up operation, CNB officers escorted the driver to his residential unit and found more drugs. In total, 5 g of Ice, 224g of Ecstasy and 1,000 Erimin-5 tablets were found in the car and about 30g of Ice was found in his residential unit. Investigations are ongoing. CNB will continue to work closely with our Home Team agency colleagues and persevere with our rigorous enforcement efforts to keep Singapore drug-free.OneHomeTeam
